mdma.spatial.periodic module¶

Module defining helper functions for distance calculations in periodic boundary conditions.

mdma.spatial.periodic.delta(x1, x2, box_dimensions)[source]¶

Displacement between two sets of points in a d-dimensional periodic space.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box_dimensions (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

Returns

x2 - x1 but with displacements wrapped inside the box boundaries (i.e. the nearest image convention).

Return type

delta (numpy.ndarray)

mdma.spatial.periodic.distance(x1, x2, box_dimensions, correct_drift=False)[source]¶

Distance between two sets of points in a d-dimensional periodic space.

This functions analagously to numpy.spatial.cdist.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box_dimensions (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • correct_drift (bool) – Whether to correct for drift in the centre of mass.

Returns

The n distances i.e. \(\{|\vec{x}_2^{(k)} - \vec{x}_1^{(k)}|\}_{k=1}^n\), where displacements are wrapped inside the box boundaries (i.e. the nearest image convention).

Return type

delta (numpy.ndarray)

mdma.spatial.periodic.self_intermediate_scattering_function(x1, x2, box_dimensions, q=6.283185307179586)[source]¶

Self intermediate scattering function between two configurations of points.

The correlation function is defined as the Fourier transform of the self part of the van Hove function:

\[F(\vec{x}_1, \vec{x}_2; \vec{q}) = \frac{1}{N} \left\langle \sum_{k=1}^N \exp{\left(i \vec{q} \cdot \left( \vec{x}_1^{(k)} - \vec{x}_2^{(k)} \right) \right)} \right\rangle\]

where \(\mathbf{q}\) is the wave vector of the Fourier transform. This implementation assumes isotropy, so the exponential reduces to a sinc function and only the magnitude of the wavevector matters so \(q\) is a scalar. \(|\vec{q}|\) is typically taken to be \(2\pi / \sigma\).

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • q (scalar) – Magnitude of the wavevector, typically taken as \(2\pi / \sigma\) where \(\sigma\) is the typical particle size.

Returns

The self-intermediate scattering function (\(F\) in the above equation).

Return type

F (scalar)

mdma.spatial.periodic.self_overlap(x1, x2, box_dimensions, tol=0.3)[source]¶

Self overlap between two configurations of points.

Overlap is defined as:

\[Q(\vec{x}_1, \vec{x}_2; \delta) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{k=1}^N \Theta\left( \left| \vec{x}_1^{(k)} - \vec{x}_2^{(k)} \right| - \delta \right)\]

where \(\Theta(\cdots)\) is the Heaviside step function, \(\vec{x}_{\{1,2\}}^{(k)}\) indicates the kth particle position in the each system and \(\delta\) is a small parameter that determines whether particles are sufficiently close to be considered to overlap. \(\delta\) is typically taken to be \(0.3\sigma\) where \(\sigma\) is the (effective) particle diameter.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box_dimensions (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • tol (bool) – Tolerance to count an overlap (\(\delta\) in the above equation).

Returns

The self-overlap (\(Q\) in the above equation).

Return type

overlap (scalar)
